meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Deadliest Suicide Attack Against G.I.'s in Months Four American soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber plowed his car into a military checkpoint in Baghdad, the single deadliest suicide bombing against an American target in more than four months. Suicide car bombings against American soldiers are rare. In Husayba, near Iraq's border with Syria, several marines were wounded in the third day of fighting there.
PAGE A11

Becoming a Butterfly to Save an Endangered Butterfly Francisco Gutiérrez, above right, joined for part of his flight by Andrew Donaldson of England, flew his ultralight 4,375 miles from Montreal to Mexico to track the migration of monarch butterflies, which are endangered by climate change and logging in their wintering grounds.
PAGE A12
Intelligence Budget Revealed In an apparent slip, a top American intelligence official revealed what has long been kept secret, the annual budget for spy agencies: $44 billion.
PAGE A18
Novelist John Fowles Dies The British writer, who played with literary conventions and blurred the boundaries between fiction and reality, was 79.
PAGE A25
Azerbaijan Vote Fraud Cited International election observers have reported fraud in the parliamentary elections held Sunday in Azerbaijan.
PAGE A3
Bonuses on Wall Street Bonus season is approaching on Wall Street, and investment bankers, the financial experts who arrange mergers and acquisitions, are expected to be first in line.
PAGE C1

Eagles Say Enough Is Enough Philadelphia said Terrell Owens, its star wide receiver, would no longer play on the team, citing an accumulation of conflicts, most notably with quarterback Donovan McNabb.
SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1

Birds Do It, Frogs Don't . . . Scientists are beginning to take a closer look at the sleep patterns of the animal kingdom, even amphibians. They are hoping to shed light on the evolutionary history of human slumber as well as the fundamental question of why sleep even exists.
SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1
